issue.title: Need docs/faq for new Halide contributors

labels.name: documentation
labels.description: Missing, incorrect, or unclear. Spelling & grammar mistakes.

issue.body: It's not clear to dev contributors how to e.g. debug the compiler vs debugging the runtime, what the overall compilation flow looks like, etc. We should have something like README_contributing.md

comment.body: In light of addressing these and others in the Wiki, what's up with the GSoC pages? Can they go, or be moved to a subdirectory in the wiki specifically for GSoC? I couldn't find any up-to-date info on the official GSoC website. @steven-johnson @vksnk

issue.title: Scheduling directive to hoist the storage of the function

labels.name: release_notes
labels.description: For changes that may warrant a note in README for official releases.

issue.body:
This PR adds a new directive which allows to hoist a storage of the function to the specified loop level. This is different from Func::store_at, because hoist_storage simply moves an actual allocation to a given loop level and doesn't trigger any of the optimizations such as sliding window. Hoisting storage is optional and can be used as an optimization to avoid unnecessary allocations by moving it out from an inner loop.

hoist_storage can be used together with Func::store_at and Func::fold_storage (for example, to hoist the storage allocated
after sliding window optimization).

comment.body: Is it possible the custom malloc is returning something with insufficient alignment on x86-32? I don't see anywhere that should matter though...

commits.message: Change debug level to get more info about segfault

labels.name: release_notes
labels.description: For changes that may warrant a note in README for official releases.

issue.body:
This PR adds a new directive which allows to hoist a storage of the function to the specified loop level. This is different from Func::store_at, because hoist_storage simply moves an actual allocation to a given loop level and doesn't trigger any of the optimizations such as sliding window. comment.body: Huh, looks like a legit test failure on the windows build bot. I can't find much information in the build bot logs other than it was a SEGFAULT and it's not reproducible for me on mac or linux, I guess I will have to push a commit with more debugging info enabled.

issue.title: If you store_at without a compute_at, the error message isn't very good:

comment.body:
In that branch it's better, but still not ideal:
```
Error:
Functions that are compute_inline() must also have store_at and hoist_storage set to inlined, but Func "f0" is store_at() "loop_level(.__root)" and hoist_storage() "loop_level(.__root)"
```

There's no store_at_inline, so it's a bit confusing. Also our printing of the loop level isn't very friendly. 

I think the ideal error message would be something like:

```
Error:
Func "f0" is scheduled store_root(), but is inlined. Funcs that use store_at or store_root must also call compute_at or compute_root.
```

and then something similar if hoist_storage is set without a compute_at. I'll leave this issue open for now to tweak the wording, but we shouldn't delay the hoist_storage PR on it.

issue.title: If you store_at without a compute_at, the error message isn't very good:

comment.body: I've fixed it together with hoist_storage in #7915 .

issue.title: If you store_at without a compute_at, the error message isn't very good:

pull_request.title: [Xtensa] Adds a pass to lift allocations out of the loop
pull_request.body:
This pass is only called for Xtensa codegen and is only applied to stack or dynamic allocations in local on-chip memory. Potentially, it could be used on other platforms as well if needed (with hopefully only few adjustments).

This requires two traversals of the IR, which are implemented within a single pass, because they need to share a lot of code. Hopefully, the implementation is not too confusing.

I've tested it extensively on our internal pipelines and see significant performance gains in some cases. Ideally, I would like to add a separate test for it, but since this is Xtensa specific, it's going to be dependent on adding testing infrastructure for Xtensa first (I hope I can return to working on it very soon).

repo.name: Halide
repo.description: a language for fast, portable data-parallel computation

issue.title: Speedup the VizIR HTML.
issue.body: Read comments below to follow along. Overall, for my large Stmt HTML file, I got the time down from close to 15s to less than 2s.

comment.body: Tagging this with release notes so that we remember to list the improvements to the visualizer.

commits.message: WebAssembly JIT does not support custom allocators

issue.title: Inject profiling for function calls to 'halide_copy_to_host' and 'halide_copy_to_device'.

labels.name: dev_meeting
labels.description: Topic to be discussed at the next dev meeting

issue.body:
This is the first time I'm writing code to manipulate the IR tree. I'm not quite sure if this is the right way to do this: I actually want to wrap the `Call*` op, but decorating that with additional Stmts seems to be something I can't do, so I'm manipulating the surrounding `LetStmt`, as generated by https://github.com/halide/Halide/blob/d023065f6c1e299e26e17ff6fb35aa4db9b2d1ff/src/InjectHostDevBufferCopies.cpp#L21-L27

Unlike `malloc` and `free` function-ids, I opted to lazily fetch them when the function call is actually encounter, to avoid adding these lines to the profile report for CPU-only functions.

---

Example of the impact on my pipeline where I had a bug of one Func that was accidentally scheduled on CPU, and required some copies back and forth, which I didn't notice. Before this PR:

```
neonraw_multiscale_denoiser_f12_Gk3_Nk7
 total time: 294.014740 ms  samples: 278  runs: 3  time/run: 98.004913 ms
 average threads used: 0.377698
 heap allocations: 9  peak heap usage: 73208804 bytes
  halide_malloc:                                        0.000ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  halide_free:                                          0.000ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  luminance_guide:                                      2.116ms (2%)    threads: 1.000  peak: 24421764 num: 3         avg: 10699254
  blur_pass_h:                                         10.917ms (11%)   threads: 1.000  peak: 24405596 num: 3         avg: 10689806
  blur_pass_v:                                         10.201ms (10%)   threads: 1.000  peak: 24381444 num: 3         avg: 10675708
  filter_input_guide:                                   1.056ms (1%)    threads: 1.000 
  blur_x2:                                              3.527ms (3%)    threads: 1.000 
  luminance_noisy:                                      6.703ms (6%)    threads: 1.000 
  filter_input_noisy:                                   0.353ms (0%)    threads: 1.000 
  denoised:                                            63.129ms (64%)   threads: 0.033 
  allocgroup__denoise_conv_guide_global_wrapper$0:      0.000ms (0%)    threads: 0.000  stack: 4
```

After this PR:

```
neonraw_multiscale_denoiser_f12_Gk3_Nk7
 total time: 304.260193 ms  samples: 287  runs: 3  time/run: 101.420067 ms
 average threads used: 0.365854
 heap allocations: 9  peak heap usage: 73208804 bytes
  halide_malloc:                                        0.000ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  halide_free:                                          0.000ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  copy_to_host:                                        14.468ms (14%)   threads: 1.000 
  copy_to_device:                                       9.906ms (9%)    threads: 1.000 
  luminance_guide:                                      1.058ms (1%)    threads: 0.333  peak: 24421764 num: 3         avg: 10699254
  blur_pass_h:                                          3.883ms (3%)    threads: 1.000  peak: 24405596 num: 3         avg: 10689806
  blur_pass_v:                                          4.589ms (4%)    threads: 1.000  peak: 24381444 num: 3         avg: 10675708
  filter_input_guide:                                   0.352ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  blur_x2:                                              2.481ms (2%)    threads: 1.000 
  luminance_noisy:                                      0.353ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  filter_input_noisy:                                   0.705ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  denoised:                                            63.620ms (62%)   threads: 0.022 
  allocgroup__denoise_conv_guide_global_wrapper$0:      0.000ms (0%)    threads: 0.000  stack: 4
```

As you can see, the time attributed moved from `blur_pass_h` and `blur_pass_v` to the copy-to-host and copy-to-device functions.

---

**Discussion**:

 - In the end, one could argue that the devices copies are part of the producer/consumer in which they sit, but if `malloc` and `free` get there own timer-slot, I think these also deserve a separate slot to profile their time.
 - Currently, restoring the original "current_func" being profiled to the current consumer/producer, might be redundant if multiple copies happen sequentially. You'd get:
    ```cpp
    set_current_func(blur_pass_v); // <-- immediately overwritten as well.
    set_current_func(copy_to_host);
    copy_to_host();
    set_current_func(blur_pass_v); // <-- redundant!
    set_current_func(copy_to_host);
    copy_to_host();
    set_current_func(blur_pass_v);
    ...
    // actual code for blur_pass_v
    ...
    ```
    Not optimal, but not worth the effort to try to optimize this debugging feature any further, IMO.

comment.body:
> > In long pipelines this may make it hard to pinpoint where the time is actually spent. For profiling halide cuda code I usually just give up and use nvidia tools to get a full cpu and gpu timeline.
> 
> Drawing from the CUDA (not Halide) optimization experience, I often find "tracing" tools more effective than "profiling" tools.

That is what he meant with the "full cpu and gpu timeline".

> What I mean by "tracing": I export the nvprof report (or nsys in the latest CUDA toolchain) to the [Google Trace Format](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1CvAClvFfyA5R-PhYUmn5OOQtYMH4h6I0nSsKchNAySU/preview#heading=h.yr4qxyxotyw) via [a script](https://github.com/ezyang/nvprof2json). Then, visualize the Gantt-chart style multi-track time traces on the chrome://tracing online app. Finally, identify the critical path of the entire algorithm run.

Why not use the NVIDIA GUI for this? `nsys-ui`? I would assume you get much more information for a similar interface.

![nsys-ui](https://i.imgur.com/i76FdGC.pngl)

issue.title: Inject profiling for function calls to 'halide_copy_to_host' and 'halide_copy_to_device'.

labels.name: dev_meeting
labels.description: Topic to be discussed at the next dev meeting

issue.body:
This is the first time I'm writing code to manipulate the IR tree. I'm not quite sure if this is the right way to do this: I actually want to wrap the `Call*` op, but decorating that with additional Stmts seems to be something I can't do, so I'm manipulating the surrounding `LetStmt`, as generated by https://github.com/halide/Halide/blob/d023065f6c1e299e26e17ff6fb35aa4db9b2d1ff/src/InjectHostDevBufferCopies.cpp#L21-L27

Unlike `malloc` and `free` function-ids, I opted to lazily fetch them when the function call is actually encounter, to avoid adding these lines to the profile report for CPU-only functions.

---

Example of the impact on my pipeline where I had a bug of one Func that was accidentally scheduled on CPU, and required some copies back and forth, which I didn't notice. Before this PR:

```
neonraw_multiscale_denoiser_f12_Gk3_Nk7
 total time: 294.014740 ms  samples: 278  runs: 3  time/run: 98.004913 ms
 average threads used: 0.377698
 heap allocations: 9  peak heap usage: 73208804 bytes
  halide_malloc:                                        0.000ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  halide_free:                                          0.000ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  luminance_guide:                                      2.116ms (2%)    threads: 1.000  peak: 24421764 num: 3         avg: 10699254
  blur_pass_h:                                         10.917ms (11%)   threads: 1.000  peak: 24405596 num: 3         avg: 10689806
  blur_pass_v:                                         10.201ms (10%)   threads: 1.000  peak: 24381444 num: 3         avg: 10675708
  filter_input_guide:                                   1.056ms (1%)    threads: 1.000 
  blur_x2:                                              3.527ms (3%)    threads: 1.000 
  luminance_noisy:                                      6.703ms (6%)    threads: 1.000 
  filter_input_noisy:                                   0.353ms (0%)    threads: 1.000 
  denoised:                                            63.129ms (64%)   threads: 0.033 
  allocgroup__denoise_conv_guide_global_wrapper$0:      0.000ms (0%)    threads: 0.000  stack: 4
```

After this PR:

```
neonraw_multiscale_denoiser_f12_Gk3_Nk7
 total time: 304.260193 ms  samples: 287  runs: 3  time/run: 101.420067 ms
 average threads used: 0.365854
 heap allocations: 9  peak heap usage: 73208804 bytes
  halide_malloc:                                        0.000ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  halide_free:                                          0.000ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  copy_to_host:                                        14.468ms (14%)   threads: 1.000 
  copy_to_device:                                       9.906ms (9%)    threads: 1.000 
  luminance_guide:                                      1.058ms (1%)    threads: 0.333  peak: 24421764 num: 3         avg: 10699254
  blur_pass_h:                                          3.883ms (3%)    threads: 1.000  peak: 24405596 num: 3         avg: 10689806
  blur_pass_v:                                          4.589ms (4%)    threads: 1.000  peak: 24381444 num: 3         avg: 10675708
  filter_input_guide:                                   0.352ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  blur_x2:                                              2.481ms (2%)    threads: 1.000 
  luminance_noisy:                                      0.353ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  filter_input_noisy:                                   0.705ms (0%)    threads: 0.000 
  denoised:                                            63.620ms (62%)   threads: 0.022 
  allocgroup__denoise_conv_guide_global_wrapper$0:      0.000ms (0%)    threads: 0.000  stack: 4
```

As you can see, the time attributed moved from `blur_pass_h` and `blur_pass_v` to the copy-to-host and copy-to-device functions.

---

**Discussion**:

 - In the end, one could argue that the devices copies are part of the producer/consumer in which they sit, but if `malloc` and `free` get there own timer-slot, I think these also deserve a separate slot to profile their time.
 - Currently, restoring the original "current_func" being profiled to the current consumer/producer, might be redundant if multiple copies happen sequentially. You'd get:
    ```cpp
    set_current_func(blur_pass_v); // <-- immediately overwritten as well.
    set_current_func(copy_to_host);
    copy_to_host();
    set_current_func(blur_pass_v); // <-- redundant!
    set_current_func(copy_to_host);
    copy_to_host();
    set_current_func(blur_pass_v);
    ...
    // actual code for blur_pass_v
    ...
    ```
    Not optimal, but not worth the effort to try to optimize this debugging feature any further, IMO.

comment.body:
> In long pipelines this may make it hard to pinpoint where the time is actually spent. For profiling halide cuda code I usually just give up and use nvidia tools to get a full cpu and gpu timeline.

Drawing from the CUDA (not Halide) optimization experience, I often find "tracing" tools more effective than "profiling" tools.

My use cases often require repeating the same iteration by N times, similar gradient descent.
To optimize for the end-to-end compute time, I take advantage of system pipelining to hide the kernel compute time in the data transfer time. Even better, utilize the duplex Host-to-device and D2H data bus to further hide the two way data transfer time.

What I mean by "tracing": I export the `nvprof` report (or `nsight` in the latest CUDA toolchain) to the [Google Trace Format](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1CvAClvFfyA5R-PhYUmn5OOQtYMH4h6I0nSsKchNAySU/preview#heading=h.yr4qxyxotyw) via [a script](https://github.com/ezyang/nvprof2json). Then, visualize the multi-track time traces on the `chrome://tracing` online app.

Profiling is still helpful for fine-grained optimization of one specific GPU kernel; I only use it only when my algorithm is compute bound.
Oh, yeah, that's better for sure.

pull_request.title: Scheduling directive to hoist the storage of the function
pull_request.body:
This PR adds a new directive which allows to hoist a storage of the function to the specified loop level. This is different from Func::store_at, because hoist_storage simply moves an actual allocation to a given loop level and doesn't trigger any of the optimizations such as sliding window. Hoisting storage is optional and can be used as an optimization to avoid unnecessary allocations by moving it out from an inner loop.

hoist_storage can be used together with Func::store_at and Func::fold_storage (for example, to hoist the storage allocated
after sliding window optimization).

labels.name: release_notes
labels.description: For changes that may warrant a note in README for official releases.

repo.name: Halide
repo.description: a language for fast, portable data-parallel computation

issue.title: Introspection doesn't support dwarf v5
issue.body:
If you want Funcs and Vars to name themselves automatically, you need to add -gdwarf-4 as a compiler flag.

We should add support for dwarf 5
